channel.description: Recent content on Poems for Pessimistic Seniors

item.title: Advantages Of A College Education
item.description:
Those who read my poems know
The place where I was forced to grow
Was by the docks, all grey and gritty
But what I longed for was the city,

item.title: Wedding Congratulations
item.description: When Matthew finally got married (we had given up hope!) I wrote this for his wedding

item.title: The Swimsuit
item.description:
My daughter has a new house,
She says it is the rule
That anyone who stays there
Has to use the pool.

item.title: HMOs
item.description: When I was working as a nurse, the hospital held a limerick competition for St. Patrick’s day. I won a potted shamrock for my efforts!

item.title: Memories Stirred By The Nightly News
item.description:
I know you think it is a bore
When I go on about the war
But every day the nightly news
Treats us all to awful views
Of homes turned into rubble
And then it turns to trouble
As the memories flood in

item.title: A False Economy
item.description:
Mum reached the age of 86
And found herself in quite a fix
Of stomach pains she had a bout
She had to have some stuff cut out

item.title: A Date For An Old Widow
item.description:
It’s not a husband that I seek
For once I had the best
But someone who is also lost
And wants to use the time that’s left.

item.title: Death of My Husband
item.description:
My husband’s dead
He hasn’t “passed”
Or gone to a better place
He’s dead.

item.title: On Turning 80
item.description:
When one gets to 80
The problems are weighty.

Not only ones health
And protecting the wealth

item.title: A Child's View of War
item.description:
There was a shelter in the yard
Of corrugated iron
The government provided it
To give us safe environs.

item.title: Fun With Breast Cancer
item.description:
I’m sitting on the table
And the doctor looks at me
The biopsies are back,
And you do have the big C.

item.title: Reflections on Chair Yoga
item.description:
My chair yoga is for those
who can no longer touch their toes.

We hobble in on cane and brace
And sit in our allotted place.

item.title: about
item.description: My friend Diane and I (both close to 80) were discussing how inadequate and miserable all those octogenarians climbing Kilimanjaro and getting PhDs made us feel. We decided a different approach was needed for the 90% of us who will never do those things. So, we call it humorous reality! Here are my efforts. Pam. The site is put together and maintained by her son, Matt Williams. You can reach him at @technovangelist on Twitter.
